questions.name: new_institution_monitoring_update
questions.label: New institution or monitoring update?

tooltip.text: Entry of institution data in RTMIS (first time) or update of monitoring data (existing institution)

questions.name: institution_village
questions.label: Which community is the institution in?

tooltip.text: Select the location of the institution: community name and, where required, ward and subcounty

questions.name: institution_geolocation
questions.label: Geo-location of the institution

tooltip.text: Record GPS coordinates of a central place in the institution (e.g. in front of entrance)

questions.name: institution_type
questions.label: Type of institution

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: type of institution (located within community). Institution: any public or private building that provides open access to toilets and handwashing facilities (to residents or users of the building).

questions.name: institution_ID
questions.label: Institution ID

tooltip.text: ID/Name: enter the name of the institution (for example, name of school or name of health facility) with, where available, an ID code. If no code is available, just enter the name

questions.name: institution_respondent_role
questions.label: Institution respondent: role in institution

tooltip.text: Institution respondent: person from the institution who is providing information. For example, head teacher, or doctor, or owner/manager.

questions.name: functional_institutional_toilet
questions.label: 2.1 G3-6.1.1C Functional institutional toilet

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: functional toilets observed in institution? Functional toilet: the institutional toilet is functioning as intended, and can be used (that is, is not blocked, abandoned or collapsed)

options.label: All toilets in the institution are functional

questions.name: num_functional_toilets
questions.label: 2.2 G3-6.1.2C Number of functional toilets

tooltip.text: Number of functional toilets: count the number of separate toilet stances or separate toilet seats that are FUNCTIONAL (each of which can be used privately and separately). Functional toilet: the institutional toilet is functioning as intended, and can be used (that is, is not blocked, abandoned or collapsed)

questions.name: num_non_functional_toilets
questions.label: 2.3 G3-6.1.3C Number of non-functional toilets

tooltip.text: Number of non-functional toilets: count the number of separate toilet stances or separate toilet seats that are NON-FUNCTIONAL. Non-functional toilet: the institutional toilet is NOT functioning as intended, and cannot be used (that is, the toilet is blocked, abandoned, collapsed or otherwise non-functioning)

questions.name: flyproof_institutional_toilet
questions.label: 2.4 G3-6.1.4C Flyproof institutional toilet

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: flyproof toilets observed in institution. Flyproof toilet: toilet design prevents flies from reaching the excreta in the pit (or tank/other).

options.label: All institution toilets are NOT flyproof
Some institution toilets  are NOT flyproof

questions.name: clean_institutional_toilet
questions.label: 2.5 G3-6.1.5C Clean institutional toilet

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: clean toilets observed in institution. Clean toilet: floor, pan and walls of toilets should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials).

options.label: All institution toilets are NOT clean
Some institution toilets  are NOT clean

questions.name: durable_toilet_slab
questions.label: 2.6 G3-6.1.6C Durable institutional toilet slab

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: durable toilet slabs observed in institution? Durable toilet slab: the range of materials considered durable will depend on local contexts. The County Public Health Office should approve the use of resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans, functionality and cleanliness to toilet slabs made from durable materials. Examples: Concrete toilet slab 2. Concrete toilet slab covered with ceramic tiles; 3. Structural plastic slab; 4. Durable hardwood floor covered with cement.

options.label: All institution toilet slabs are NOT durable
Some institution toilet slabs are NOT durable
All institution functional toilet slabs are durable

questions.name: durable_toilet_pits
questions.label: 2.7 G3-6.1.7C Durable institutional toilet pits

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: durable toilet pits observed in institution? OBSERVE: are there any signs of collapse or damage to the toilet pits or tanks (or connections)? INTERVIEW (where pit or tank not visible): were any materials used to support the sides of the toilet pits (or tanks)?
INTERVIEW (where pit or tank not visible): does the soil in this area collapse without structural support? INTERVIEW (where pit or tank not visible): have any toilet pits (or tanks) in this area collapsed in the last 12 months
Durable toilet pit (in stable soils): unlined pits may be assessed as durable in areas where other unlined pits are known to be stable and long-lasting. Durable toilet pit (in UNSTABLE soils): pits (or tanks) should either be lined with durable materials, or lined with resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans and support to linings made from durable materials.

options.label: All institution toilet pits are NOT durable
Some institution toilet pits are NOT durable
All institution functional toilet pits are durable

questions.name: excreta_contained_in_pits
questions.label: 2.8 G3-6.1.8C OBSERVATION: Excreta contained in pits (or tanks)

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: any evidence of surface outflows from containment systems (for example, visible outflows or leaks; increased vegetation growth around the pit; visible deposits from previous outflows),
Surface outflows from containment: EITHER continuous outflows of faecal sludge or wastewater from overflow pipes, holes or leaks; OR evidence of previous surface outflows (for example, increased vegetation growth around the containment system, or visible sludge deposits from overflows or leaks).

options.label: Evidence of previous surface outflows from containment

questions.name: safely_managed_faecal_sludge_containment
questions.label: 2.9 G3-6.1.9C INTERVIEW: have any pits (or tanks) ever been emptied?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: has the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever been emptied?,
INTERVIEW: has the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever filled up?,
INTERVIEW: what happened when the institutional toilet containment (pit, tank or other) last filled up?
Never emptied: current pit is not yet full, and has NOT been emptied Intention to empty: planning to empty toilet pits (or tanks) when full, or when required. Examples: 1. Covered full pits and dug new pits; 2. Emptied full pits and re-used; 3. Connected a second pit and disconnected the full pit. 4. Emptied faecal sludge from tanks then continued to use.]

options.label: Toilets with no pits or tanks (open discharge)
Pit or tank overflows to open
Never emptied (intention to empty when full)
Never emptied, no intention to empty
Never emptied (previous pits replaced: NO intention to empty)
EMPTIED: contents removed from ALL pits (or tanks)
EMPTIED: contents removed from SOME pits (or tanks)
Closed containers removed (transported out of community)

questions.name: contents_emptied_to
questions.label: 2.10 G3-6.1.10C INTERVIEW: where were the pit (or tank) contents emptied to?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: the last time pits were emptied, where were the contents of the toilet pits (or tanks) emptied to? INTERVIEW: the last time pits were emptied, who emptied the toilet pits (or tanks)? INTERVIEW (if pit contents stored): How long were pit contents stored (without any fresh excreta entering the toilet pit or tank) before emptying? Storage time: length of time that contents of pit or tank were stored without any fresh excreta entering the pit (for example, alternating twin pit latrine where full pit is disconnected and contents are stored for 2 years before emptying)
Licensed service provider: paid emptier that is approved and regulated by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes Unlicensed service provider: paid or unpaid emptier who is NOT approved by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes (for example, family members, neighbours, friends, informal local emptiers) Off-site location: site for the treatment, disposal or use of toilet wastes that is away from the institution, whose location may or may not be known.
Sewer connection to licensed and functional treatment site: the Public Health Office should check whether the sewer network flows to a licensed and functional treatment or disposal site. Open container: bucket or other open container used to collect excreta (usually regularly collected and emptied).

options.label: Toilets with no pits or tanks (open discharge)
Closed containers removed by UNLICENSED worker
Closed container removed by UNLICENSED worker (transported out of community)
Stored for less than 2 years before emptying
NOT emptied (intention to empty when full)
Sewer connection to UNLICENSED or NON-FUNCTIONAL treatment site
EMPTIED by LICENSED worker (transported out of community)
EMPTIED to nearby covered pit (buried within community)
Closed containers removed by LICENSED worker
Stored for MORE than 2 years before emptying
Sewer connection to LICENSED and FUNCTIONAL treatment or disposal site

questions.name: community_low_groundwater_contamination_risk
questions.label: COMMUNITY LEVEL ASSESSMENT: Low risk of groundwater contamination

options.label: G0 High risk of groundwater contamination
G2 Low risk of groundwater contamination

questions.name: outcome_safely_managed_usable_institutional_toilets
questions.label: Outcome result - Safely managed and usable institutional toilets

fn.fnString: #functional_institutional_toilet#.includes("g0") && #flyproof_institutional_toilet#.includes("g0") && #clean_institutional_toilet#.includes("g0") && #durable_toilet_slab#.includes("g0") && #durable_toilet_pits#.includes("g0") && #safely_managed_wastewater_containment#.includes("g0") && #safely_managed_faecal_sludge_containment#.includes("g0")  && #safely_managed_sanitation_services#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Institutional sanitation services UNSAFELY managed" : (#functional_institutional_toilet#.includes("g3") && #flyproof_institutional_toilet#.includes("g3") && #clean_institutional_toilet#.includes("g3")  && #durable_toilet_slab#.includes("g3") && #durable_toilet_pits#.includes("g3") && #safely_managed_wastewater_containment#.includes("g3") && #safely_managed_faecal_sludge_containment#.includes("g3") && #safely_managed_sanitation_services#.includes("g3")) ? "G3 Use of safely managed institutional sanitation services" : "G1 Inadequate institutional sanitation services"

questions.name: handwashing_facility_institution
questions.label: 2.13 G3-6.2.1C OBSERVATION: Handwashing facility observed in institution

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: presence and location of handwashing facility

INTERVIEW: is there only one handwashing facility, or are other facilities available?

options.label: Portable handwashing facility (basin, jug, jerrycan, container)

questions.name: number_functional_handwashing_facilities
questions.label: 2.14 G3-6.2.2C OBSERVATION: Number of functional handwashing facilities

tooltip.text: Number of functional handwashing facilities: count the number of separate handwashing facilities that are functional (each of which has its own water supply and soap supply, can be used separately, and is working as intended).

questions.name: number_non_functional_handwashing_facilities
questions.label: 2.15 G3-6.2.3C OBSERVATION: Number of Non-functional handwashing facilities

tooltip.text: Number of non-functional handwashing facilities: count the number of separate handwashing facilities that are NOT functional (NOT working as intended)

questions.name: water_available_institutional_HWF
questions.label: 2.16 G3-6.2.4C OBSERVATION: Water available at institutional handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is water available at all of the handwashing facilities?
INTERVIEW: is water always available for washing hands (even in dry season)?
Evidence of washing: where an empty water container is observed at the handwashing facility, visible wet ground (or wet materials) under the handwashing facility can be accepted as proof of the recent presence of water.
Seasonal water availability: where water is not available in the dry season (or at other times), the outcome should be marked as “Water NOT always available”

options.label: Some handwashing facilities have water available
All handwashing facilities have water available
All facilities either have water available or evidence of washing

questions.name: soap_available_institutional_HWF
questions.label: 2.17 G3-6.2.5C OBSERVATION: Soap available at institutional HWF

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is soap available at the handwashing facility?,
INTERVIEW: is soap or detergent available for washing hands?
Soap: solid, liquid or powder soap or detergent

options.label: No soap or other cleanser available
Only ash, mud or sand available
Some handwashing facilities have soap available
Soap available, NOT at handwashing facility
All handwashing facilities have soap available

questions.name: institutional_HWF_type
questions.label: 2.18 G3-6.2.6C OBSERVATION: Institutional handwashing facility type

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: what is the main type of handwashing station? Select option appropriate for most handwashing facilities in the institution.
Permanent handwashing station: facility made from durable materials, with piped water connection or adequate water storage, and located in a fixed place that is appropriate for handwashing at critical times. Temporary handwashing facility: tippy tap or other facility made from non-durable materials.
Portable bowl: open container that can be picked up and moved.

options.label: Jerrycan (or other open container) with NO lid
Jerrycan (or other closed container) with lid
Portable bowl or other open container
Permanent handwashing station with water storage

questions.name: hands_free_operation_institutional_HWF
questions.label: 2.19 G3-6.2.7C OBSERVATION: Hands-free operation of institutional handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: main mechanism to collect water or trigger water flow? Select option appropriate for most handwashing facilities in the institution.
Hands-free operation: handwashing stations are operated by tap, or other hands-free mechanism that minimises contact with the water collection device and the water container

options.label: Water collected by hand (using ladle, cup, other)
Closed water storage container with tap

questions.name: adequate_drainage_washing_water
questions.label: 2.20 G3-6.2.8C OBSERVATION: Adequate drainage of washing water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: facility to collect washing water, and facility to drain and dispose of the washing water
Collection of washing water: container to collect dirty washing water (for example, a basin or other container)
Drainage and disposal of washing water: drainage pipe or other facility to direct the washing water to an appropriate disposal point (for example, a soakpit or drain)

options.label: No collection or disposal of washing water
Collection of washing water without drainage or disposal
Safe collection and disposal of washing water

questions.name: outcome_permanent_handwashing_stations_in_institution
questions.label: Outcome result - Permanent handwashing stations in institution

fn.fnString: #handwashing_facility_institution#.includes("g0") && #water_available_institutional_HWF#.includes("g0") && #soap_available_institutional_HWF#.includes("g0") && #institutional_HWF_type#.includes("g0") && #hands_free_operation_institutional_HWF#.includes("g0") && #adequate_drainage_washing_water#.includes("g0") ? "G0 No or inadequate handwashing services" : (#institutional_HWF_type#.includes("g3") && #hands_free_operation_institutional_HWF#.includes("g3") && #adequate_drainage_washing_water#.includes("g3")) ? "G3 Permanent handwashing services" : "G1 Non-durable handwashing services"
